ï»¿Execution Version b 7 Dated October 9, 2014 COLLABODRATION ARRANGEMENT relating to Global Intrastructure Facility Partnership Program
ï»¿Execution Version This Collaboration Arrangement is entered into on October 9, 2014 between: (1) CITIBANK, N.A., a National E;anking Association, with offices at 388 Greenwich Street, NE tA 'I rk, NY 10013, USA ("Citibank"); and (2) THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTION AND DHVELOPMENT ("IBRD") and INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPIV EIl ASSOCIATION ("IDA"), head juartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC 20433 US\, ie INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION, ("IFC") headquartered at 2121 Pennsylvan E Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20433, USA, and the MULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY, ("M GA"), headquartered at 1818 H Street, NW, Washington, DC : C 33, USA (the "World Bank Group") (each a "Party" and together, the "Parties"). Preamble (A) There is broad international recognition, as confirmed by the G20, the OECD, Interr Elti: lal Organizations (lOs), the G77 and the private sector represented by the B20 that investin I r "he infrastructure of Emerging Markets and Developing Economies (EMDEs) is needed, to :::p nd access to basic services and raise living standards for all, and to meet global economic crc vth targets. (B) Meeting this need presents a significant financing challenge. Given constraints on ! i,; ng sources of infrastructure finance-particularly in the public sector-a redoubled and coor:fii: ed effort is needed to mobilize pr vate sector finance for EMDE infrastructure. (C) There is an absence of robu ;t pipelines of structurally sound and bankable projects anc hi is understood to be the greatest barrier to achieving significantly more infrastructure investme r t. (D) Governments, development fiiance institutions, donors, and private investors share an int lie in developing the market for priiate infrastructure finance in EMDEs: both on the demand i:l: in the numbers of structurally scind and bankable projects seeking finance, and gradual emer;E ice of EMDE infrastructure as a ecognized asset class; and the supply side, in the range of pri ate investors that actively particiate in financing those projects. Achieving these goals will te efit from collective action betwe n this range of entities-to leverage resources and knowl( clgI to find solutions to complex irfrastructure financing challenges that no single institutior c: uld achieve alone. (E) In support of these goals, the Parties propose the establishment of a Global Infrastructure 1= I: lity Partnership Program ("GIF"). The GIF will be an open global platform aiming at leverac ir g the efforts of the wide range of ir stitutions currently engaged in supporting EMDE infrastructh r:! ,ith the participation of private infrastructure investors, coalescing around project prep nala :n, structuring, and risk mitigatic n for individual infrastructure investments. In this regard, I : IF aims to complement existing and proposed services and initiatives currently supported t y the Parties and other prospective GIF partners. The GIF intends to provide resources to prepa E ' ell- structured, infrastructure pro.ects, and to serve as an additional mechanism for access rig the expertise of the Parties and Dther GIF partners, in combination with guidance from proE ive private sector financiers into Iiroject structures. The GIF thereby aims to achieve greater IE v ige of official resources in the faie of substantial EMDE infrastructure needs-in particular fi r I -ge and complex projects with the potential to attract significant private capital. (F) The Parties are now interes ed in collaborating in developing the Global Infrastructure 1=:a lity Partnership Program, together with other partners. 1
ï»¿Execution Version Accordingly, the Parties have com( to the following understanding: 1 Global Infrastructure FacilitI Partnership Program Framework 1.1 The GIF is intended to be based on the preliminary objectives and principles set o t in Annex 1 (Preliminary GIF Foc ndational Principles). The Parties acknowledge their mutual understanding that while the GIF Foundational Principles are an initial basis for their collat o,a on, they are of an indicative nature and will continue to be developed amongst the Parties and A it other potential partners until tie GIF is formally established. The final version of these obje :ii s and principles will be agreed upon by the GIF Partners and be reflected in the agreement establishing the GIF. 1.2 The Parties intend to Nork together with any additional participants who may be collaborating on the GIF to further enhance their coordination, in particular by developing tl ( IF, with a view to formally establi;hing the program by December 2014. 2 Further Collaboration 2.1 Pursuant to the foregoing, the Parties will use reasonable endeavors to continue tc collaborate in developing the 31F, including but not limited to: a. Nature and scope of collaboration under the GIF, such as proposed categories of partnership and the roles, rights, and responsibilities associated with each categor, b. Governance arranger ients of the GIF; c. Operational policies applicable to the GIF's operations; d. Scope of GIF activitie3 and sources/uses of GIF funds, including approach to proje: selection criteria and ,oordination with the Parties' existing facilities; and e. Any other aspects of :ollaboration required to finalize the design of the GIF, includ ni:J sharing best practice 3nd experience with regard to project preparation, through th a u: a of knowledge platforn is for the infrastructure sector. 2.2 During the process of finaliz ng the design of the GIF, the multilateral development bank ; ii red in Annex 2 will be invited to participate as initial Technical Partners. Once the GIF d( sic is finalized, additional collaborative efforts are required to develop the operational details F:,r he GIF, at all times complemEnting existing efforts and facilities and building upon the si ved knowledge and experience of the Parties in this area. This includes determining the a,,( of coordination between the Parties and project origination process. 3 General 3.1 This Collaboration Ar angement is not a legally binding agreement or commitment : e Parties to enter into or provide support for any specific activity or project. The Parties acknowledge that the provisicns of this Collaboration Arrangement represent their commor understanding and intentions only and that the Parties do not intend to create or impose ar y I: gal obligations or liabilities on an) Party. 3.2 This Collaboration Ar angement is valid and effective for a period of one year from the w date thereof, unless superseced at an earlier date by the establishment of the GIF. 3.3 The Parties expect th 3t this document and information with respect to the collabor it v activities contemplated hereir will be publicly disclosed. Such disclosure will be made in accordance with the Parties' respective disclosure policies. The Parties plan to consult witt iz :h 2
ï»¿Execution Version other concerning the manner and form of any acknowledgment of the other Party's suppor regarding the activities. 3.4 Nothing in this arrang ament will constitute or be construed as a waiver, renunciatic'I other modification of any of th a privileges, immunities and exemptions granted to any of thE Parties under their constituen documents, international conventions and any applicable law , In witness whereof, each of the Partes has caused this Collaboration Arrangement to be execute:1 ir two (2) counterparts of equal content nd form by a duly authorized representative of each Party a, iof he date first set forth above. 3

ï»¿Execution Version THE WORLD BANK GROUP, comprising the INTERNATIONAL BANK FOR RECONSTRUCTIO? I fk1 D DEVELOPMENT, the INTERNATION lL DEVELOPMENT ASSOCIATION, the INTERNATIONAL FINANCE CORPORATION and the NIULTILATERAL INVESTMENT GUARANTEE AGENCY By: JWM1 NG KIM, PRESIDEN1 5
ï»¿Execution Version Annex I Prelin inary GIF Foundational Principles 1 Objectives 1.1 The objective of the (IF is to promote private sector investment in infrastructure pi : e ts in emerging markets and devoloping economies (EMDEs) through robust project preparatilr , provision of appropriate risk mitigation instruments, and thereby increasing the commercial zn institutional investor engagerr ent in the EMDE infrastructure market. It is focused on collaboration in complex publi,-private partnerships and projects with potential for commer:i viability which require project )reparation resources, policy dialogue and eventual infrastrut ii financing solutions that no single institution could achieve alone. 1.2 To this end, the GIF a ims to create a global platform to provide financial and coord ra )n resources in collaboration with the project preparation, advisory, and financing efforts of thi i le range of donor and developm ant finance institutions currently engaged in supporting EMDI infrastructure, with the input aid ideas of private infrastructure investors. GIF's engagemer t :ld stretch from upstream suppor: on project definition, preparation, and investment feasibility assessment, through to down stream transaction preparation, financial structuring, and risk mitigation/credit enhancemen:. 1.3 Over the longer term, by contributing to the stock of high quality and well-structure I infrastructure projects, the GIF can be expected to help in the development of EMDE infrastructure as an asset clas s attractive to a wide range of private investors seeking long. 1:0r i assets in faster growing econrmies, but which until now have been presented only limited infrastructure investment opportunities that meet their risk tolerance and investment profile:,. 2 Operating Principles 2.1 The GIF intends to or erate according to the following core principles, to be finalize :1 u on agreement among GIF partners: (i) Leveraging the private sector-specializing in project financing modalities th - ill draw together comparative advantages of public and private sectors; (ii) Addressing pub ic goods-focusing on core infrastructure; particularly those infrastructure pro ects that are climate friendly or trade enabling; (iii) Promoting susti inability and inclusiveness-ensuring projects adhere to b ?t practice standard s for social and environmental responsibility; and (iv) Collaborating, c >mplementing and partnering for solutions-mobilizing te:: in :al and financial resc urces of all partner entities-World Bank Group entities, mul 1:1i ral development inst tutions, other public institutions, and private investors-in an innovative and flexible way, to complement existing capacities, achieve greate leverage and adcress the complex infrastructure financing challenges that are beyond the resoL rces of any individual partner. 3 Institutional Arrangements and Governance 3.1 The GIF is expected o involve a wide range of stakeholders who are involved in tI1= development and implementation of infrastructure projects, both public and private. GIF pa ti, s are expected to fall into one cr more of the following categories: 6
ï»¿Execution Version (i) Funding Partner s-Partners that provide financial contributions to the GIF wil n considered Fundi ig Partners. (ii) Technical Partners-Partners that can and who will agree to provide specific technical advice a nd support to GIF activities including execution of GIF-funde: activities and/or provision of GIF-backed credit enhancement or liquidity suppc 1 instruments. (iii) Advisory Partne m-Private investors or entities that represent the voice of commercial and/c r institutional investment, whether pension funds, insurance companies, soveieign wealth funds, banks or other financial institutions, as wE I other multilateral )r bilateral agencies engaged in supporting private sector infrastructure pro ects, to be invited into discussions related to project preparal c n. optimal approach as to financial structuring, and the design and use of risk instruments, with a view to ensure suitability of projects for commercial and/or institutional inves ment. 3.2 A GIF Governing Council is proposed to oversee the GIF's strategic programmin, management and use of fund ;, and development of operational policies and procedures; a I1 hold the GIF Management Urit (see section 4.1) accountable for delivering on the facility's objectives and principles, wit[ advice and support from the Advisory Partners. The compoE it cl of the Governing Council will be agreed between IBRD and prospective partners, but is propc sa to comprise representatives of Funding and Technical Partners. 3.3 An Advisory Counci comprised of all GIF partners, chaired by the Managing DirE:oc and Chief Financial Officer of the World Bank Group, will be periodically convened to facilit v e coordination of GIF activities and support GIF operations. This Advisory Council will serve In sounding board, providing guidance and support for GIF Management, and in particular wili E view to ensuring suitability of )rojects for private sector investment. 4 Management 4.1 The GIF will be admir istered by the World Bank Group, through a small, dedicatec ti ,:n established for this purpose (tie GIF Management Unit). The GIF Management Unit will fu lcti n as a coordinating body as prclects are identified for inclusion in the pipeline, and then mov: toward technical support and inancing phases. The GIF Management Unit will not lead inc i id ial projects. 4.2 GIF activity implemertation teams will be led by selected staff of Technical Partnei institutions, coordinated by th a GIF Management Unit in consultation with client goverrimei t;, according to specific project r equirements and the project origination processes. Composi icr )f the implementation teams may vary according to the need of individual projects and gover in nts. 5 Activities and Projects 5.1 Project selection criteria and processes could be developed to reflect the follow ir g principles: (i) Development Impact-projects that support the development goals of the Gil partner institution s; (ii) Alignment-proj )cts that are aligned with recipient/sponsor country priorities ic strategies; (iii) Complexity-prc jects that require multiple parties to come together to providE structuring, arran 3ing and financial support, and/or projects which require a bl r d >f financial instrumE nts; and 7
ï»¿Execution Version (iv) Catalytic Impact-projects that have significant potential to achieve financial ia. lity, leverage public ft nds, and attract private sector and/or institutional investors- s.i 1 as through Public-Private Partnership (PPP) modalities-while still meeting government's serice delivery objectives. The GIF will focus on infrastri cture investments that have global public good characteristic s! ich as climate friendly-projects that are low emitting or encourage efficiency in the provisior f infrastructure services; and tr ade enabling-projects that facilitate or enhance interconnei tv and trade. 5.2 The scope of suppo t provided to a particular project will be defined flexibly, with vi w to complementing the resources and support already available from partner entities and ot ler funding mechanisms. During he GIF pilot phase, this support may include the following ac i-i' is, corresponding to major project development stages: (i) Project definition and enabling environment - sector planning and investment prioritization; proj act definition, including needs analysis and pre-feasibility scr! r ig; and legal, regulatbry, or institutional reforms; (ii) Project preparati(n and investment feasibility - feasibility studies, investment appraisal, and PF P structuring; (iii) Transaction support and financial structuring - preparing and implementing transactions, and design of risk mitigation/credit enhancement packages; and (iv) Financial arrangii ig and credit enhancement - arranging and mobilizing financi -iI packages from a -ange of sources and partners. 6 Operational Policies Sound operational policies-i icluding in particular the management of environmental and ;e- i1 impacts and risks, and transparency in procurement-are critical to the success of infrastrt c ti e projects in supporting sustain able, inclusive development; as well as for investors in those projects to manage financial, eputational and legal risks. In developing the appropriate framework for GIF-supported operations, the GIF could draw upon existing arrangements i:) external implementing entities under World Bank Partnership Programs. GIF partners will collaborate to establish an ap Droach to fiduciary, environmental and social safeguards and c : !r standards and policies, and d avelop, manage and oversee an accreditation process for GI Technical Partners who are e(pected to function as implementing entities for GIF activities 8
